title: PNC Refund Radar Inc
rawDocument: I. Strategic Identity ● Feature Name: PNC Refund Radar ● Product Pillar: Virtual Wallet / Cash Flow Management ● Target Persona: High-frequency online shoppers (Gen Z/Millennials) who utilize 'Buy Now, Pay Later' or return items frequently. ● The 'Magic Moment': Receiving a notification the moment a merchant initiates a refund, even before the money hits the ledger, so the user knows they 'won' the dispute or return. II. The Problem Space (Deep Dive) ● The Micro-Friction Event: A user returns a $200 jacket to a retailer. They check their transaction history daily for 7 days. Because the refund date often differs from the return date, they have to scroll back through weeks of data to see if the credit arrived. ● Data Blind Spots: Users cannot see the difference between a 'Pending Credit' and a 'Settled Credit.' They also don't know if a partial refund (e.g., $180 vs $200) is due to a restocking fee or a bank error. ● Psychological Hurdle: 'Financial Limbo.' The user feels they have $200 'missing' in the world, which prevents them from making other necessary purchases, leading to a feeling of being out of control. ● Existing Workarounds: Users keep screenshots of return receipts or keep 'Return' emails marked as unread in their inbox until they manually verify the credit in the PNC app. ● The Cost of Inaction: High volume of 'Where is my money?' calls to PNC support; customers perceiving the bank as 'slow' even when the delay is on the merchant’s end. III. Strategic Constraints & Inputs ● Integrations: Must pull data from ISO 8583 transaction messaging (specifically looking for 'Credit' indicators) and integrate with the Virtual Wallet 'Calendar' view. ● The 'North Star' Policy: Must adhere to Reg E (Electronic Fund Transfers) regarding the timing of when credits must be made available to the customer. ● The 'Do-Not-Touch' List: The feature should NOT allow the user to spend the refund until the funds are officially settled/cleared, to avoid overdraft risk if the merchant reverses the credit.
summary: The product solves refund uncertainty by providing early refund initiation notifications, distinguishing pending from settled credits, and offering contextual explanations for discrepancies. It targets Gen Z and Millennial online shoppers and BNPL users who experience frequent returns and financial uncertainty. The feature aligns with PNC’s goals to improve transparency, reduce support inquiries, enhance Virtual Wallet, and maintain regulatory compliance while differentiating PNC through proactive refund visibility.

productIdeas: Real-time notifications when merchants initiate refunds, before settlement appears in the ledger
Clear distinction between pending credits and settled credits
Refund tracking integrated into Virtual Wallet calendar view
Contextual explanations for partial refunds (e.g., restocking fees)
A consolidated refund timeline to eliminate manual tracking or inbox reminders

marketSizing.highFrequencyShoppers: Large and growing population of Gen Z and Millennial online shoppers with high return rates
marketSizing.bnplUsers: Expansion opportunity based on increasing adoption of Buy Now, Pay Later services
marketSizing.supportCostReduction: Significant volume of customer service calls regarding refund status could be reduced
marketSizing.ecommerceGrowth: Rising e-commerce transaction volume increases refund friction pain points

customerSegments: Gen Z and Millennial online shoppers
Users who closely monitor cash flow due to budgeting constraints
businessGoals: Reduce customer support volume related to refund inquiries
Improve customer trust by increasing transparency into refund processes
Enhance Virtual Wallet’s value as a cash flow management tool
Position PNC as a proactive and customer-centric banking experience
Prevent overdraft risk while keeping customers informed
scenarios: Customer returns an item and wants immediate confirmation that the merchant initiated a refund
Partial refunds occur and customers need clarity on the discrepancy
Users check transaction history repeatedly due to uncertainty around refund timing
Integration with transaction messaging and settlement constraints must be honored
Feature must communicate refund status without allowing premature fund access
customerNeeds: Visibility into when refunds are initiated
A clear distinction between pending and settled credits
Reduction in financial uncertainty during refund waiting periods
A frictionless way to track returns without manual workarounds
stage1Analysis.competitiveInsights: Few banks provide real-time initiated-refund notifications or clear pending vs. settled credit visibility, especially integrated into cash-flow tools like a wallet calendar. Early transparency creates differentiation versus competitors perceived as slow or opaque in refund processing.

epics.name: Refund Detection & Ingestion
epics.description: Identify and ingest merchant-initiated refund signals from ISO 8583 and map them to user accounts.

epics.name: Refund Status Visibility
epics.description: Display clear distinctions between pending and settled refunds within transaction history and wallet.

epics.name: Refund Notifications
epics.description: Provide real-time alerts when refund initiation is detected, before funds settle.

epics.name: Refund Detail & Explanations
epics.description: Surface contextual information such as partial refund reasons and expected timelines.

epics.name: Calendar Integration
epics.description: Integrate refund projections and events into the Virtual Wallet calendar view.

epics.name: Refund Tracking Hub
epics.description: Provide a consolidated view of all active and past refunds, eliminating the need for manual tracking.

userStories.story: As a high-frequency shopper, I want the system to detect refund initiation from ISO 8583 messages, so that I know the moment a merchant begins the refund process.
As a user, I want pending refunds to appear distinctly from settled refunds, so that I don’t confuse them with completed credits.
As a user, I want a mobile push notification when a refund is initiated, so that I’m immediately aware without checking my ledger.
As a user, I want to see the estimated settlement window for a pending refund, so that I can plan my cash flow.
As a user, I want the app to show me whether a refund is full or partial, so that I can understand unexpected differences.
As a user, I want an explanation for partial refunds, such as restocking fees, so that I don’t assume a bank error.
As a user, I want refund events to appear in my Virtual Wallet calendar, so that I see how they affect future cash flow.
As a user, I want the calendar to distinguish between expected (pending) and confirmed (settled) refunds, so that I don’t mistakenly assume funds are spendable.
As a user, I want a consolidated refund tracking screen, so that I no longer need to rely on screenshots or flagged emails.
As a user, I want to know which transaction a refund is associated with, so that refund tracking is understandable.
As a user, I want to receive an alert when a pending refund fails or is reversed, so that I know the merchant did not complete it.
As a user, I want refunds clearly marked as unavailable‑to‑spend until settled, so that I don’t accidentally overdraft.
As a user, I want the app to show me the original purchase amount and date when viewing a refund, so that my financial timeline is clear.
As a user, I want to filter refunds by status (pending/settled) in the tracking hub, so that I can quickly confirm what’s still outstanding.
As a user, I want to receive a notification when a refund fully settles, so that I know it is officially available.

acceptanceCriteria.storyRef: As a high-frequency shopper, I want the system to detect refund initiation from ISO 8583 messages, so that I know the moment a merchant begins the refund process.
criteria: Given a merchant sends a credit indicator in the ISO 8583 message, When it is received by the system, Then the refund should be classified as an initiated refund.
Given a malformed ISO 8583 message, When parsing fails, Then the system logs an error and does not generate a false refund event.

acceptanceCriteria.storyRef: As a user, I want pending refunds to appear distinctly from settled refunds, so that I don’t confuse them with completed credits.
criteria: Given a refund is initiated, When the user views the transaction list, Then the refund is labeled as Pending.
Given a refund settles, When the ledger updates, Then the refund label changes to Settled.
Given a refund was initiated but later reversed by the merchant, When the user opens the ledger, Then the pending refund is removed and a reversal note is displayed.

acceptanceCriteria.storyRef: As a user, I want a mobile push notification when a refund is initiated, so that I’m immediately aware without checking my ledger.
criteria: Given a refund initiation event is detected, When the event is processed, Then the user receives a push notification.
Given the user has disabled notifications, When the refund is initiated, Then no push is sent.

acceptanceCriteria.storyRef: As a user, I want the app to show me whether a refund is full or partial, so that I can understand unexpected differences.
criteria: Given a refund amount is less than the purchase amount, When shown in the UI, Then it is labeled as Partial refund.
Given the merchant sends an amount equal to the original total, When shown in the UI, Then it is labeled as Full refund.

acceptanceCriteria.storyRef: As a user, I want an explanation for partial refunds, such as restocking fees, so that I don’t assume a bank error.
criteria: Given merchant metadata includes fee details, When a partial refund is displayed, Then the explanation is shown.
Given no metadata is available, When viewing the refund, Then the app displays 'Merchant may have applied fees.'

acceptanceCriteria.storyRef: As a user, I want refund events to appear in my Virtual Wallet calendar, so that I see how they affect future cash flow.
criteria: Given a pending refund exists, When the user views the calendar, Then the refund appears on the expected settlement date.
Given the expected date changes, When updated in the system, Then the calendar automatically adjusts.

acceptanceCriteria.storyRef: As a user, I want a consolidated refund tracking screen, so that I no longer need to rely on screenshots or flagged emails.
criteria: Given the user has active refunds, When they open the tracking hub, Then all refunds appear with their statuses.
Given the user has no pending refunds, When opening the hub, Then a no-pending-refunds message is displayed.

acceptanceCriteria.storyRef: As a user, I want to know which transaction a refund is associated with, so that refund tracking is understandable.
criteria: Given a refund has a corresponding purchase match, When viewed in the UI, Then the original transaction details are displayed.
Given multiple purchases have identical amounts, When matching fails, Then the app prompts 'Unable to match automatically.'

acceptanceCriteria.storyRef: As a user, I want refunds clearly marked as unavailable‑to‑spend until settled, so that I don’t accidentally overdraft.
criteria: Given a refund is pending, When viewing account balance, Then the pending amount is not included in available balance.
Given a refund is settled, When the ledger updates, Then the credit is added to available balance.

acceptanceCriteria.storyRef: As a user, I want to receive a notification when a refund fully settles, so that I know it is officially available.
criteria: Given a refund status changes from pending to settled, When the system updates, Then a settlement notification is triggered.
Given the user disabled notifications, When settlement occurs, Then no notification is sent.

later: Calendar integration with expected settlement dates

assumptions: Merchant refund metadata is reliably available for at least major retailers.
ISO 8583 credit indicators are consistent enough to detect refund initiation.
Push notification infrastructure exists and can be reused.
Calendar integration APIs already exist in Virtual Wallet.
Reg E compliance rules are already modeled in settlement logic.
Matching refunds to purchases is possible for at least 90% of cases.

evidence: (synthetic) I hate refreshing my account for days just to see if my refund showed up.
(synthetic) I returned a pair of shoes and kept checking my balance like 20 times. No clue if the store even processed it.
(synthetic) Not knowing if a refund is coming makes me feel like money is in limbo.
feedbackThemes.impact: High emotional friction, repeated app checks, and unnecessary support calls.
feedbackThemes.opportunity: Provide early notifications and clear refund status indicators to reduce anxiety and increase trust.

evidence: (synthetic) By the time the refund posted, it was buried under like two weeks of transactions.
(synthetic) I end up scrolling and scrolling to figure out if the money came back.
(synthetic) I keep screenshots of my returns because it’s impossible to track in the app.
feedbackThemes.impact: Users feel they must create manual tracking systems.
feedbackThemes.opportunity: Offer a unified refund timeline and calendar view integration.

evidence: (synthetic) I got refunded $185 instead of $200 and had no idea why.
(synthetic) Did the merchant take a fee or did the bank mess up? No clear explanation.
(synthetic) Partial refunds always make me suspicious something’s wrong.
feedbackThemes.impact: Creates mistrust and perceived bank errors.
feedbackThemes.opportunity: Provide contextual explanations for refund amount differences.

feedbackThemes.theme: Need for More Transparency Before Funds Settle
evidence: (synthetic) I wish I knew the second a refund was initiated.
(synthetic) Other apps tell you when something is pending—why can't my bank?
(synthetic) I want visibility without actually spending the refund.
feedbackThemes.impact: Lack of transparency leads users to check more often and feel out of control.
feedbackThemes.opportunity: Introduce clear 'pending vs. settled' visuals while maintaining compliance and preventing spending.

feedbackThemes.theme: High-Frequency Online Shoppers Expect Real-Time Feedback
evidence: (synthetic) I shop online constantly—refunds are just part of life now.
(synthetic) BNPL makes returns more complicated; I need to know what's happening instantly.
(synthetic) Fast notifications are how everything works now… except refunds.
feedbackThemes.impact: Expectation gap between modern digital behaviors and banking processes.
feedbackThemes.opportunity: Differentiate through proactive refund visibility similar to modern commerce platforms.

competitorComparison.strength: Reliable transaction posting and simple UI.
competitorComparison.weakness: No early refund initiation alerts; no pending vs. settled clarity.
competitorComparison.gapWeExploit: Provide earlier awareness and richer refund context.

competitorComparison.weakness: Alerts trigger only after settlement, not initiation.

competitorComparison.strength: Fast push notifications and modern UX.
competitorComparison.weakness: No dedicated refund-tracking tool or partial-refund explanations.
competitorComparison.gapWeExploit: Offer purpose-built refund tracking integrated into budgeting tools.

competitorComparison.weakness: Limited nuance in transaction status communication.
competitorComparison.gapWeExploit: Surface transaction-level metadata from ISO 8583 for refund clarity.

competitorComparison.weakness: Not optimized for frequent online returns; no proactive refund visibility.
competitorComparison.gapWeExploit: Target shoppers who return merchandise frequently.

competitorComparison.strength: Strong real-time notifications tied to merchant activity.
competitorComparison.weakness: Refund visibility depends entirely on merchant timing; no refund timeline.
competitorComparison.gapWeExploit: Expand beyond notifications into a refund management experience.

competitorComparison.strength: Shows pending and completed refunds clearly.
competitorComparison.weakness: Not integrated with full cash-flow or budgeting tools.
competitorComparison.gapWeExploit: Blend refund transparency with broader money management.

competitorComparison.strength: Highly transparent refund and return flows.
competitorComparison.gapWeExploit: Provide Klarna-level visibility for all refund types across all merchants.

trends.trend: Real-time financial visibility expectations driven by Gen Z and commerce apps
trends.implication: Banks that fail to offer instant status updates risk appearing outdated.

trends.trend: Increasing volume of online returns and BNPL transactions
trends.implication: Refund uncertainty will grow unless financial institutions enhance visibility.

trends.trend: Greater use of ISO 8583 metadata for enriched transaction experiences
trends.implication: Banks can differentiate by using deeper transaction data for proactive insights.

trends.trend: Shift toward proactive vs reactive financial notifications
trends.implication: Early refund notifications align with broader industry movement toward anticipatory financial tools.

trends.trend: Customers expect banks to act like retail apps (Amazon, Klarna)
trends.implication: Banks that mimic commerce-grade transparency will gain trust and loyalty.

trends.trend: Rising regulatory focus on transparency around electronic fund transfers
trends.implication: Clear status messaging supports compliance and reduces disputes.

insights: Refund uncertainty generates more emotional stress than the refund delay itself.
Users already track refunds manually, showing unmet needs that a built-in tool could solve.
Partial refunds are a major misunderstanding driver, often attributed incorrectly to bank error.
High-frequency returners represent a fast-growing segment who value transparency over speed.
Early visibility could significantly reduce refund-related support contact volume.
opportunities: Deliver a real-time refund initiation notification before settlement posts.
Create a unified refund timeline with pending, initiated, and settled states.
Integrate refunds into the Virtual Wallet calendar to improve cash-flow visibility.
Provide merchant-contextual explanations for partial or delayed refunds.
Differentiate PNC through transparency features competitors lack.
risks: Users may misunderstand pending refunds as available funds, risking overdrafts.
Merchants may reverse initiated refunds, causing confusion if not clearly communicated.
Data availability from ISO 8583 may be inconsistent across merchants.
Over-notification could irritate users if not tuned correctly.
Regulatory compliance requires careful wording around credit timing.
nextResearchSteps: Conduct diary studies of users who frequently return online purchases.
Run concept testing on pending vs settled refund UI distinctions.
Interview customer support agents to map refund-related call drivers.
Validate feasibility with engineering regarding ISO 8583 refund indicators.
Test notification language for clarity around non-spendable funds.
assumptions: ISO 8583 consistently identifies refund initiation events.
Users prefer early awareness even if funds are not yet available.
Partial refund explanations can be reliably inferred or sourced.
Gen Z and Millennials represent the highest-need target segment.
The feature will meaningfully reduce refund-related support calls.

entryPoints: Push notification: 'Refund initiated for your recent return'
Virtual Wallet Calendar: upcoming credits view
steps: User lands on Refund Detail screen showing pending vs. settled state
User views refund timeline: initiated → processing → expected settlement
User expands 'Details' for any partial refund explanation
User optionally adds reminder or views it in the Calendar
User returns later to see settlement confirmation
userFlow.description: Flow guides users from early refund notification into a clear refund status view, highlighting pending credits and timeline until settlement.

wireframes.purpose: Alert user the moment the merchant initiates a refund
Show refund status, timeline, and pending vs. settled state
Give users a clear, step-by-step view of refund progress
Show upcoming refund credit on the Virtual Wallet calendar
Confirm settled credit and close loop on user anxiety

usabilityTestScript.script: You just received a refund notification for an item you returned. Show me where you would tap to learn more.
You are unsure whether the refund has settled. Show me how you confirm its current status.
You notice the refund is less than expected. Show me where you would go to understand why.
You want to know when the refund will arrive. Show me how to view its estimated date on your calendar.
After a few days, you want to check if the refund settled. Show me how you confirm this.

testCases.case: Notification tap leads to correct screen
testCases.expectedResult: Refund Detail screen loads with correct data

testCases.steps: User opens Refund Detail and scrolls timeline
testCases.expectedResult: Nodes show initiated, processing, estimated settlement
Explanation module appears with fee reason
Refund appears on expected date in calendar

testCases.steps: System changes refund state to settled
testCases.expectedResult: Status badge updates and funds show as available
Timeline shows multiple events, amounts itemized
Refund card appears in activity feed

testCases.steps: Partial refund but no reason provided
testCases.expectedResult: Fallback copy appears: 'Your merchant issued a partial refund'
Updated date reflected with banner: 'Refund timeline updated'
Status updates to 'Refund canceled' without releasing funds

testCases.steps: User opens Refund Detail on poor network
testCases.expectedResult: Skeleton loaders appear until data arrives

testCases.steps: User views a refund from 45 days ago
testCases.expectedResult: Timeline collapses to summary with settlement confirmed

iteration.feedback: Users confused by difference between initiated vs pending
iteration.change: Rename badge to 'Refund started (not yet credited)'
Add concrete merchant timestamps when available

iteration.feedback: Users want to know 'what to expect next'
iteration.change: Add mini-stepper under status: 'Next: settlement check'
Auto-add refund to calendar with opt-out toggle

iteration.feedback: Partial refund explanation hard to find
iteration.change: Place explanation directly under refund amount

iteration.feedback: Users want confirmation they won the refund
iteration.change: Add celebratory microcopy: 'Your refund is on the way!'

assumptions: ISO 8583 credit initiation indicators are reliably available
Settlement windows vary by merchant but can be estimated
No early spend allowed until official settlement
Calendar can accept refund events without violating policy

personas.name: The High-Frequency Online Shopper
goals: Know exactly when a refund is initiated so they can plan cash flow
Feel in control of their money during return cycles
pains: Constant uncertainty about when refunds will land
Difficulty distinguishing pending vs settled credits
Anxiety that funds are ‘missing’ during the return process
triggers: Feeling cash-constrained while waiting for a refund
objections: Will I mistakenly think I can spend the money early?
personas.keyMessage: Know the moment your refund is initiated so you can stay in control of your cash flow.

personas.name: The Budget-Conscious Planner
goals: Predict upcoming credits to avoid overspending
Track refund timing within their financial calendar
pains: Needing to cross-check merchant emails with banking activity
triggers: Pending large purchases dependent on expected refunds
objections: Will the feature explain why a refund amount changed?
Will this clutter my notification feed?
personas.keyMessage: See refund timing clearly so you can budget with confidence.

messaging.positioningStatement: PNC Refund Radar gives customers real-time visibility into refunds the moment merchants initiate them, removing financial uncertainty and helping users plan their cash flow with confidence.
benefits: Clear separation of pending and settled credits
Full transparency with refund timelines and explanations
proofPoints: Powered by ISO 8583 credit indicators for early detection
Integrated with Virtual Wallet’s Calendar for cash-flow planning
Supports Reg E compliance and protects customers from premature spending
taglines: Know your refund the moment it starts.
See your money coming back sooner.

launchGoals: Reduce refund-related customer support calls by 15% within 60 days
Increase Virtual Wallet engagement and daily active users
Position PNC as a leader in proactive banking transparency
channels: In-app education cards highlighting Refund Radar
Push notification spotlight for early-refund detection
Email campaign to high-frequency online shoppers
Social and digital ads targeting Gen Z and Millennials
Branch and call-center scripts for customer education
gtmPlan.rollout: Closed beta with 5% of Virtual Wallet users, followed by a phased rollout to 25%, then general availability to all eligible customers within 8 weeks.
risks: Merchant-initiated credits may be reversed, leading to confusion
Customers may assume pending credits are spendable

releaseNotes.customerFacing: Introducing PNC Refund Radar: Get notified the moment a merchant initiates a refund, even before the money posts to your account. Track pending vs settled credits and understand refund amounts with clear explanations, all integrated into your Virtual Wallet Calendar.
releaseNotes.internal: Refund Radar adds early visibility into merchant-initiated credits using ISO 8583 indicators. Notifications display refund initiation without making funds available until cleared. Support teams should remind customers that pending refunds cannot be spent. Compliance review confirms adherence to Reg E timing rules.

stakeholderComms.execs: Refund Radar strengthens our Virtual Wallet strategy by reducing customer uncertainty around refunds, a top driver of support calls. The feature differentiates PNC with proactive transparency and drives higher engagement for Gen Z and Millennial users. Early metrics will focus on call reduction and feature adoption.
stakeholderComms.engineering: Refund Radar requires ingesting ISO 8583 credit indicators to detect merchant-initiated refunds before settlement. Build a pending-credit state in the ledger and deliver a real-time push notification. Integrate the refund timeline into the Virtual Wallet Calendar. Ensure no spend-access is provided before settlement.
stakeholderComms.support: Customers will now receive notifications when merchants initiate refunds. These are pending and not spendable until posted. If customers ask about discrepancies (e.g., partial refunds), advise them to check the explanation in the app. Escalate only if the refund exceeds standard merchant timelines.

Early reduction in ‘Where is my refund?’ support calls

Customer satisfaction score improvement for refund processes

Users opt in to push notifications within the Virtual Wallet experience
